conclusion: Analyze the processes involved in the Stirling cycle and the properties of the gas during transitions.
The Stirling cycle consists of four processes: A→B, B→C, C→D, and D→A. A→B and C→D are isothermal processes.
During isothermal processes, the temperature of the gas remains constant, and internal energy remains unchanged.
The processes B→C and D→A are adiabatic, meaning no heat is exchanged with the surroundings.
During adiabatic processes, the temperature of the gas changes. Temperature decreases during adiabatic expansion (B→C).
During the transition from B to C, an adiabatic expansion occurs, causing a decrease in internal energy and temperature.
The thermal motion of gas molecules is directly related to the temperature of the gas.
As the temperature decreases during the adiabatic expansion from B to C, the thermal motion of the gas molecules becomes less intense.
The thermal motion of gas molecules does not become more intense when transitioning from state B to state C.
Final Answer: No, the thermal motion of gas molecules does not become more intense when transitioning from state B to state C.
